user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_SocketGetInfo(osal_id_t sock_id, OS_socket_prop_t *sock_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sock_prop);

    memset(sock_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_socket_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, token);

        strncpy(sock_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(sock_prop->name) - 1);
        sock_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code        = OS_SocketGetInfo_Impl(&token, sock_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_SocketGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME]; /**< @brief Name of the socket */
    osal_id_t creator;               /**< @brief OSAL TaskID which opened the socket */
} OS_socket_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset(sock_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_socket_prop_t));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The memset call uses sizeof(OS_socket_prop_t) and the function parameter is typed as OS_socket_prop_t*. This is safe provided the caller supplies a pointer to a valid object of type OS_socket_prop_t. A violation would only occur if the caller incorrectly passed a pointer to a smaller object or an interior pointer (e.g. a pointer to a smaller buffer or to a sub-object), causing memset to write beyond the actual object bounds.
